titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Russell Birdwell Papers LSC.0114
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Nina Scholtz in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Kelley Wolfe Bachli, 2010; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.
titlestmt.sponsor: The processing of this collection was generously supported by Arcadia funds.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-08-03 15:08:09 -0700.

did.abstract: Russell Juarez Birdwell was a reporter for Hearst Newspapers and subsequently the head of publicity for David O. Selznick (ca. 1936-193), for whom he directed the publicity campaign for Gone with the Wind. Thereafter he worked independently as publicity agent for actors and other celebrities and for American businesses. The collection pertains both to individual clients and to Birdwell's personal and professional interests, and includes extensive correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs, and press releases.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Russell Birdwell papers (Collection 114). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.
Processed by Nina Scholtz in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Kelley Wolfe Bachli, 2010.
The processing of this collection was generously supported by Arcadia funds.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Russell Juarez Birdwell was born on October 17, 1903. He worked for Hearst newspapers in Los Angeles and New York, and covered Charles Lindbergh's takeoff for Paris. He directed two silent movies in 1929 and a short in 1933. Subsequently he became the head of publicity for David O. Selznick. In February 1939 he opened his own office, Russell Birdwell and Associates, in Beverly Hills and New York, with occasional offices in London and Chicago. Among the many he publicized were actresses Carole Lombard, Marlene Dietrich, Janet Gaynor, Joan Blondell, and Jane Russell; companies Celotex and Associated Filmmakers; businessman Howard Hughes; King Carol II of Romania; and major films including Gone with the Wind and The Outlaw. In 1939 he published the autobiographical novel I Ring Doorbells. In 1941 he traveled to England and wrote the book Women in Battle Dress (1942) based on his observations. In later years he published a volume of poetry (1969) and the novel Mount Horeb (1972). He died on December 15, 1977 in Oxnard, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: These papers date almost entirely from the years 1936-1946. In this period Birdwell was employed by David O. Selznick (1936-1939) and operated his own publicity agency (1939-1946). Items include extensive correspondence and memoranda, newspaper and magazine clippings, press releases, and photographs. Materials pertain to both Birdwell's clients and to his personal and professional interests.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Client files.
Correspondence.
Personal.
Photographs.
Office.
Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains papers pertaining to Birdwell's clients and the movies, radio shows and other things that he publicized. Types of documents include correspondence and internal memoranda, newspaper and magazine clippings, and press releases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains items pertaining to specific clients.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains extensive correspondence between Birdwell and many other people. Birdwell's practice of occasionally filing newspapers clippings among correspondence has not been disturbed. Items are primarily arranged by first letter of the correspondent's surname, although occasionally items are filed by subject as noted on the item.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains items about Birdwell and his writings, including publicity releases, newspaper and magazine clippings, and newspaper and magazine articles, as well as items about Birdwell's wife, Mabel Condon, and other family members.
